content.title: SMA Stenting
content.summary: Superior mesenteric artery stenting is an endovascular treatment for mesenteric stenosis, applicable in both chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI) and select acute cases. It offers a less invasive alternative to open bypass with acceptable durability.
content.definition: Percutaneous endovascular placement of a stent in the superior mesenteric artery to restore luminal patency and improve mesenteric blood flow

chronic_mesenteric_ischemia.symptoms: Postprandial pain, food fear, weight loss
chronic_mesenteric_ischemia.single_vs_multivessel: Most benefit with multivessel disease; single SMA stenosis sufficient if collaterals limited

acute_mesenteric_ischemia.role: Adjunct to thrombolysis/aspiration for thrombotic occlusion
acute_mesenteric_ischemia.timing: After flow restoration to treat underlying stenosis
acute_mesenteric_ischemia.caution: Less applicable for embolic disease (no underlying stenosis)

anatomy_and_access.SMA_origin: Arises from aorta at L1, 1-2 cm below celiac trunk

femoral.approach: Most common, retrograde over the wire
femoral.challenges: Acute angulation may limit guide support

preparation.hydration: Adequate IV hydration for contrast load

procedural_steps: 1. Access site preparation and sheath placement

stent_selection.positioning: Ostial stents should protrude 2-3mm into aorta

technical_pearls: Embolic protection generally not used (unlike renal)
Use stiff wire for guide support
Consider kissing stent if celiac also diseased

complications.mortality: 2-5% for CMI; higher in acute setting

bypass_preference: Young patients with long life expectancy

follow_up.surveillance: Duplex ultrasound at 1, 6, 12 months, then annually
follow_up.velocity_criteria: Peak systolic velocity >300 cm/s suggests restenosis
follow_up.reintervention: Repeat angioplasty or stenting for symptomatic restenosis

learning_objectives: List indications and contraindications for SMA stenting
Describe access options and their advantages/disadvantages
Outline the procedural technique including stent selection
Compare outcomes of stenting versus open bypass
Plan appropriate surveillance after mesenteric stenting
clinical_pearls: Balloon-expandable stents preferred for ostial lesions
Ostial stents should protrude 2-3mm into aorta
Peak systolic velocity >300 cm/s on duplex suggests restenosis
Left brachial access offers better alignment with caudal SMA
Primary patency ~70-80% at 3 years; reintervention is expected
